posts.name: burde1jb
posts.cooked:
Looking for some coding help -

In short - We want to run a motor (REV Vortex with REV Spark Flex) forward while a button is pressed until a forward limit switch is trigged (Adafruit beam break sensor). The limit switch is connected to the Flex via the Data Port as the “Forward Limit Switch”.

So far this is all working as planned. What we DO NOT know how to do is how to disable the limit switch while a different button is pressed so we can then bypass the limit switch and continue to run the motor even while the limit switch is triggered.

I found the API for the limit switch here: LimitSwitchConfig (FRC-REVLib API)

I also found a Spark Max example with Limit Switches here:

But I do not know how to do this with a Spark Flex. Any advice is appreciated. Thanks!

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: That is an old example. You can see the 2025 examples at GitHub - REVrobotics/REVLib-Examples and the migration instructions that show how to use the config structure: Migrating to REVLib 2025 | REVLib

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: You can run this to set them on/off as needed.

posts.name: burde1jb
posts.cooked:
Thanks! Yes, the behavior that results from this is with Button A we can run a motor until the limit switch is tripped, then the motor stops. Or we use Button B where the motor runs and ignores the limit switch. But, these are both when the limit switch has not yet been tripped.

How can we use Button A to run until the limit switch is tripped but then use Button B while the limit switch is tripped to run the motor?

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked:
Set the limit switch enabled(true) in the initial config

gamepad(buttion b).onTrue run the suggested code gamepad(button b) onFalse run the suggested code with enabled(true)

Hold button b until off the switch

posts.name: burde1jb
icemannie
posts.cooked: You need to change the limit switch state only once when the button is first pressed - not constantly. Look at the CommandXboxController which provides on true and WhileTrue methods in place of if type state. Also what is the switch detecting?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
it sounds like you have a logic error in the code. If we simplify the && logic a bit, this is what the bot is actually doing: Having one button turn the intake on, and one button turn the change the limit switch behavior.

What you described in words would look different when put into code. That would look like this:

Note, that if the driver hits both left and right buttons at the same time, then it will run the first condition (the top one); In this case, that would halt the intake.

Another critical feature is that running motor configs commands (this guy: intakeMotor.configure(...) ) is a very slow operation: The system will wait for ~20 ms for the motor to send a reply back, and confirm that the new configuration is set. This is about 50% of your robot’s general loop time, and when you do it every loop, you’ll get loop overruns and major code failures. Instead, you want to do two things:

If you’re using Commands, put it in an initialize() call or decorator. This means you only do it when a button state changes.

use intakeMotor.configureAsync(...) ; This async version configures the motor, but does not wait for the motor to send back a reply. (or, in technical terms, it’s “non-blocking”, and asynchronous). This is much better for loops like this.

posts.name: burde1jb
posts.cooked:
tekdemo:

use intakeMotor.configureAsync(...) ; This async version configures the motor, but does not wait for the motor to send back a reply. (or, in technical terms, it’s “non-blocking”, and asynchronous). This is much better for loops like this.

I like this part. Will have to try this tomorrow with the team.

Question - One hiccup we had when trying out the “kResetSafeParameters” versus “kNoResetSafeParameters” was after we bypassed the limit switch was that the Flex continued to flash white/green at us indicating the Flex believes the hard limit was still reached and would not reset. Will the “Async” prevent the limit switch from auto resetting? Or will the true/false cases reset the limit switch upon pressing the buttons?

Note - I really do appreciate everyone’s help on this!

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
kResetSafeParameters doesn’t impact the limit switch in that way. Those clear all other settings beyond the currently selected config (such as conversion factors, current limits, and PID tunings), and is almost certainly not something you want to send mid-match.

The Spark itself will not retain memory of the switch being pressed once it’s unpressed*.

One scenario that may be at play is simply the switch wiring. Electrically, the Spark must be able to restore the wire voltage back to the “before-pressed” state. Depending on what switch you have and how the switch is wired, it may not be able to do that. Photos or diagrams of how it’s wired might help.

The typical way to wire these is as shown here, pulling the GND and 3.3V from the Rev data port. In this wiring configuration, the control pin (the forward limit pin in your case) will always be pulled to ground, or pulled to high voltage, and work reliably.

The other way to wire them is using a “pull up resistor”. This is functionally identical to the above, but you don’t need a 3.3V wire (leaving that terminal empty). In such a case, the microcontroller is responsible This is great in most cases, but in FRC specifically, I’d suggest connecting all 3 wires to your switch, as it provides better signal clarity and avoids some issues.

Another option: Your code can just query the Spark for the limit switch, without actually needing to enable the use of the hard limits. This allows your code to act on it being pressed without specific need for the Spark to do so. However, this doesn’t help if the switch itself is not returning the proper signals.

*(technically not completely true, it marks this in a Sticky Fault field; But this does not affect operation, and does not need to be handled)
